 Can redistricting be done by computer ?
 
 Can some computer software designer tell me whether the following 
 idea is technically possible ? 
 
 Congressional redistricting should be done by a computer program 
 designed to randomly aggregate geographically contiguous voters,
 mechanically stripped of political affiliation, to form appropriate
 congressional districts.
 
 This should be adopted by one or two states, and tested and
 debugged, then adopted nationally by a constitutional amendment, 
 so as to be uniformally used thruout the country.
 
 nels96

post_info.post_title: Can redistricting be done by computer ?

Well, that would require the ethnicity, political leaning, and population information of every county in the US. 
 
 So, yes, it is possible.

emoticon_confused I don`t get it...

 
 What don't you get? 
 
 The program would take data regarding race and political leaning and make completely random distracts to ensure that one particular group does not have majority in all of the counties, like Texas.

What don't you get? 
 
 The program would take data regarding race and political leaning and make completely random distracts to ensure that one particular group does not have majority in all of the counties, like Texas.

 
 Hey Duo,
 What made you supercomplicate my suggestion? The only thing we need is to simply aggregate pure undifferentiated VOTERS, no party, no race, no gender, no ethnicity, no class of any kind. The computer would simply group 
 suitable counts of neighboring VOTERS in all areas to make up appropriate congressional districts.
 
 What gets me is why this isn't the obvious way to go? "Bipartisan' commissions of retired judges is baloney, to put it kindly.
 
 nels96
